question: Question_01_(f)
sols:
Taking the derivative of the given equation yields

\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dx} f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big(x\big[f(x)\big]^2+x^2\Big) \\
 f''(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big(x\big[f(x)\big]^2\Big)+\frac{d}{dx}\Big(x^2\Big) \\
&= \big[f(x)\big]^2 + x \big[2f(x)f'(x)\big]+2x \end{align*} When \emph{x}=1, \emph{f} is equal to 2, so

\begin{align*}
 f''(1) 
&= \big[f(1)\big]^2 + (1) \big[2f(1)f'(1)\big]+2(1) \\
&= \big[2\big]^2 + \big[2(2)f'(1)\big]+2 \\
&= 6 + 4f'(1) .\end{align*} We need the first derivative of \emph{f} at \emph{x} = 1.
Using the expression we are given for the derivative of \emph{f},

\begin{align*}f'(1) 
&= (1)\big[f(1)\big]^2+(1)^2\\
&=2^2+1\\
&=5.\end{align*} Therefore,

\begin{align*}
 f''(1) 
&= 6 + 4f'(1) \\
&= 6 + 4(5) \\
&= 26.\end{align*}
hints:
Calculate $f''(x)$ by differentiating $f'(x)$. How can you use the
information about $f(1)$ to find $f'(1)$ and then $f''(1)$?
